Union Square.name: Union Square
reviews:
Every large city has this area. If you need something from clothes to prescriptions then more than likely it will be here. Prices vary from what I seen. People say it's overpriced but to be honest I was in target and Ross and they weren't different from Texas or Louisiana. Always shop around unless you are short on time then go here.
Show less
I loved shopping here! It was very pleasant. The cable cars roll right through! Little coffee cafe right in the middle there and so many wonderful shops! It kind of felt like New York :)
We enjoyed roaming through the stores, had breakfast, and enjoyed all the people watching opportunities. It was cold but sunny, so the stores were a welcome refuge!
It's great for Bars and restaurants but....

Bars and restaurants abundance, it seems to be all about the shopping. I didn't find it that exhilarating, and I LOVE to shop. It seemed to be sprawling and no real direction. Such a shame as I wanted to love 'Union Sq' but found it to be just a load of over priced shops and eateries, with not much glue. You can high end shop anywhere in the world. Macy's is consistent as usual!
Show less
A lot of high end shopping mixed with professional pan handlers and homeless people. I'm not into the really expensive shops but it is a place you should see. In the daytime.

Very high end shopping, even the Macy’s was overpriced. If you want high end, they have them all. There is a lot of construction in this area, which makes walking around a little challenge. This is a main place for the hop on hop off tour busses. There are a few street performers and a lot of homeless people. I never felt unsafe, but they do ask for change.
Show less
Lots of luxury stores to visit in the area. Great place to go for some retail therapy. Many excellent restaurants in the area as well
Shopping and people watching in the small square

The square itself is a good location for people watching. There's a nice little heart sculpture in the one corner. They had a large projection screen setup but it just seemed to be displaying ads when we were there. Otherwise, there are standard stores like Macy's in the area if you're looking for shopping. It's not a very big square with most of the seating being the sides/steps to sit on as opposed to dedicated benches. I didn't notice any public restrooms in the area.
Show less

11am dodging drug addicts lying face down on the pavement. We had food thrown at the cab we were in the streets sourniding union square are filled with homeless drug addicts. I didn't feel safe here at all. We hired a car opposite the Hilton Hotel. Followed the sat nav 2nd left into drug addict city. Couldn't get away quick enough and didn't want to return even to drop the car off. Such a shame as I looked forward to visiting this city of wonderful sights and things to do but don't bother go somewhere else we luckily stayed in fisherman's wharf which also has it's fair share of homeless but it felt a lot less threatening. Such a shame but this was the only part of my trip to US I couldn't wait to be oer
Show less

Check out the shoe floor at Macy’s, which has every style you could imagine. Head down to Westfield San Francisco Centre for more great shops, including Bloomingdales. Be sure to check out the circular escalators in the Nordstrom Center.

I have been here many times. It has a great Christmas tree and a ice skating rink over the holidays. I try to go to Santacon when I can (its a big daytime drinking party) There are stores all around it and can be very "toursty" But its a nice to hang out on a sunny day.
Show less
A shoppers paradise. Lots of stores, nice to walk around. Also, lots of eateries to choose from after shopping

I grew up coming to San Francisco to shop at Union Square. Every time, such an outing was greeted with happy anticipations and concluded with happy memories. I am a fourth generation Californian who's lived my adult life outside of the state. This January we spent a week in the city. I was shocked to see what's become of Union Square. It's third world in the worst way. When walking around you have to keep your eyes open to make sure you don't step on excrement, needles or the poor souls sleeping in the street. I've travelled extensively- nationally and internationally, and only one city I've visited can match this squalor. Even in Salvador, Brazil, you see them regularly washing the streets.
Shame on the city elders for ignoring this sorrowful plight.
Show less

This is the 2nd time I have stayed in the Union Square Dist. so great to walk by all the Big stores and window shop.
Tiffany's was on my list, but it was raining and I didn't want to track mud into that sparkling store just to "look".
It was Jan 2 and they were taking down the big Christmas tree in the Square the day we walked by. Love all the "Hearts" around town. Walking distance to many attractions. Bustling, fun area!
Show less

I was surprised, after hearing so much about Union Square, how small it is - the square itself I mea. Then I realized that Union Square actually refers to the whole surrounding area, which encompasses lots of goodies - hotels, restaurants, theatres, bars etc. The trolleys run through Powell St at the west (?) end so it's really accessible. All the grand shops are there - Hermes, Saks, Macy's, Tiffany. I was there just before Xmas and the decorations were glorious - specially at night. There is plenty of seating in the middle of the open square itself, with gardens all around, so it's actually a really sensible logical place to meet up. There was an ice skating rink set up for Christmas, where you can hire skates and equipment and pre book a session. It looked really popular and I guess it happens each Xmas. So if you're in SF next Xmas check it out. On one Saturday a couple of weeks before Xmas the Square and surrounding streets were awash with red, as EVERYONE was dressed in Santa suits and other xmas gear to party up and their Xmas shopping. It was super crowded, so depending on your penchant for socializing, Union Square may be a place you either rush to or avoid on Saturdays in December! See photo's attached and you'll see what I mean. It was nuts!
Show less
Usual shops and hustle and bustle

We came here to see what the fuss was all about but actually unless you like high end shopping it’s pretty much same same as other cities. There is Macy’s, a 9 level Westfield, including Nordstrom and the Nordstrom rack next door, Bloomingdales etc. not far is Nike town a building full of Nike gear. We tend to like sales and there didn’t seem to be that many sales. So we didn’t spend long here. There are a few homeless which is very sad. Coming from a pretty good welfare system in NZ it saddens us. Still good to have been there and done that and ticked it off our list to do in San Fran but when we come back to San Fran we may skip this area.
Show less

The Square is an inviting place to meet and sit. It routinely hosts a range of seasonal activities, and as we walked through the square today we stopped and watched the ice skating rink in full use. Around the Square are luxury boutiques and high-end stores for the discerning shopper. Plus, the terminus for the Trolley Car to Fisherman’s Wharf is a few blocks away with the never-ending line of riders waiting to board. Union Square is definitely worth a visit during any San Francisco walk about, regardless of the amount of time you wish to spend there.
Show less
Quite a busy area. Quite a few high end shops. Would appeal more to people shopping. Good selection of places to eat. Christmas tree worth a look.
Shopping area beautifully decorated for Christmas

We were there Dec 27th, so the Christmas tree was still up and decorated. Some construction was going on on the right side of the square which made heavy traffic around the area even worse. The square is filled with lots of high end department stores and designer boutiques.
Show less

This is definitely a busy open square area, good for walking around as a public space. However, the multitude of vendor stands, and other tourist magenets throughout the square area puts a damper on this space as a truly "relaxing" place to spend time at. It's good for walking around and people watching.
Show less

Union Square is the shopping area of San Francisco for people with very deep pockets because it's an expensive part of an already expensive city and so I do suggest that you blow your dough in other parts of the city where you get more back for your buck. There are several good coffee shops in the area though and Chinatown is not that far from the main square.
Show less
Visited Union Square and saw the Huge Christmas Tree
Quite an impressive X'mas Tree with big crowds! The atmosphere was lively and our trip from San Jose to see this was worth!

Though I was staying at the Ritz-Carlton on Nob Hill this time, I walked down the steps to Lower Stockton St, and down the block to Union Square. There was still construction, and the Stockton & Post corner to be even more barricaded on this visit? The project IS taking a long time, but at least most areas of the Square have remained open – though some access might be restricted.

As this visit was in November/December, I was in for a surprise – the Holiday skating rink had been installed, and was in full operations – so there was less open area in the Square. Still, folk were enjoying themselves, and especially the kids. I did not get information on how long the skating rink will be open for, but it is something to consider, if visiting during, or just after the holidays.

Otherwise, there were few changes, since my last visit, and those plantings, which have been undisturbed by the construction, or the skating rink, are still lovely.

Always a nice place to stroll, or sit and relax (weather depending), right in the heart of San Francisco.
Show less
Union square is so beautiful in winter at night. The Macy's christmas tree is huge and beautifully lit. Great place for photos. Parking is tough but worth to go.

Great place to go shopping! The shopping experience in San Francisco is unique with most of the stores in a central area and traveling between stores requires walking outside except for the Westgate Mall San Francisco Centre. A great place to go shopping when the weather is good.
Show less
Great Union Square - the Times Square of the West

Yes, it can be crowded and sometimes occupied by strange people, but it is quintessential San Francisco in one block. It is surrounded by the finest hotels, restaurants, department stores, and shops... it now also has an Apple Store. It is a great gathering place with access to the Powell Street Cable Cars and only a few blocks away from BART on Market Street. Great place to watch people go through, or play. At Christmas time, there is an ice skating rink and Macy's has a huge Christmas Tree in the Square. Wonderful magical place to be.
Show less
Fun and crowded, big Christmas tree, fast pace environment, old folks may get lost here. Very central to cable car, train station and bus stops. Big atrium for ice skating, main events vicinity.

Quite a relatively small area which gets crowded and packed very easily as it's surrounding by large department stores and seems to be the centre for Xmas celebrations within the City.

The huge Xmas tree is a selfie/photo magnet so if you simply want to walk through, good luck!
Show less

This is a park where many things and events happen. Yesterday was no exception. It was Santa Con in the City. Many city residents were wearing Santa outfits in all shapes and forms. There were all walking up and down the streets but this was a main gathering for some events. There is a tall Christmas tree in the center and again, a place to get lost. If you are with a group, have a plan where to meet before you split with each other because you can in a split second. The plaza is in the middle of all the shopping area. There are coffee shops and also many benches to sit and rest.
Show less
The Xmas tree is up as are the Macy’s decorations and the outdoor ice rink. Really puts you into the holiday spirit.
Very much enjoyed the atmosphere all around the square especially since the large Christmas tree has been lit up. It's a great place to sit and people watch.
Great shopping spot in SFO! Tiffany's, Saks, Macy's and Swarovski all feature. Whilst I was there the ice rink and Xmas tree went up and looked amazing! Shopping central!

We visited there in July, underground subway is going on , so there is a lot of waiting in that area. We will be glad when its completed. I like riding the cable cars through the city to union square.

We walked to Union Square from our hotel as we had heard it was a good place to see. We were both very underwhelmed by it. It is just a pedestrianised square surrounded by shops. We are not shoppers and therefore this did not interest us. There did not seem to be much to see or information on the history of the same which would have been more interesting to us. However, we did not spend much time there so we may have missed something. I would recommend spending your time at the wharf instead.
Show less
The commercial hub of the city of San Francisco

We stayed about a block away from Union Square at The Donatello Hotel. We quite liked the area as it was quite vibrant and gave one many options in eating shopping etc. Union Square is the commercial hub of the city of San Francisco.

You will find many hotels,department stores, boutiques shops, restaurants, nightspots and galleries in the area surrounding Union Square.

Nearby at the intersection of Powell and Market Streets it is fasinateing to view the manual cable car turnaround.

Its a great safe area to stay but expect to encounter some homeless. If you venture towards the Donatello away from Union Square a few blocks away is the Tenderloin where the mood changes and isn't a desirable place to visit after dark.
Show less
We couldn't get out quick enough. Do something ... anything ... else.

We caught the cable car to Union Square because we'd been told it was OK through the day. Well, I suppose if you like crowded, over-commercialised tourist traps then it's paradise. We couldn't wait to leave.
We had considered a hotel in this area. Thank goodness we were pre-warned by someone who had been unfortunate enough to stay there.
Don't bother. You can get the same ripped-off experience in any city without trying. Spend your time enjoying the unique aspects of this beautiful city.
Show less

Just imagine every high end store you can possibly imagine in one area. The center of it has artists in the square. It’s also close to the trolley turn around! As a tourist, I can say I’ve been there, done that, don’t need to go back.
Show less

This is one of the better areas in San Fran. More of a business area. They have many good restaurants. A bus driver (they are very friendly here) advised to go to Sixth Street and walk into Westfield Mall. I could not believe what a beautiful place. The escalators go in the round and not to be missed.Beautiful park with waterfall and just a well kept area
Show less

Stores around a square are not unique but this is San Francisco and that makes all the difference. Wander around and go into the stores if you must. Construction in the street area is huge and interesting if you look down into the deep holes.
Good spot to pick up a tour bus or watch the street traffic.
Parking much easier in public parking garage on corner of Stockton and Sutter.
Show less
Endless construction works make Union Square a disappointment for the focal point of the area. Dominated by an ageing Macy's

Disclosure: I'm not a tourist but rather a SF native.
Downtown SF has always been one of those downtowns where those who work there clear out at the end of day and the tourists who are left are confined to a small patch of Union Square-aesthetically-pleasing 'small square' surrounded by some retail shops. But venture toward Market St. or the side streets and you are in the land of dystopia. Expensive Teslas are juxtaposed against one homeless person shooting up and the other excreting on the sidewalk (I kid you not).
Consider Fisherman's Wharf, Nob Hill, or Presidio Heights as alternative hotel destinations. Or better, a cute little AirBnB in Noe Valley.
Show less

Feels like the heart and soul of San Francisco, so much to do whether it be just walking around, eating and drinking, shopping - it has it all. I normally stay in one of the hotels bordering the square and just wander in and out all day. Unlike past trips, the Square itself didn't appeal - it seems to have been modernised with more structures and doesn't have the relaxing nature where you can just sit and enjoy.
Show less
Everything seems to happen or begin from here. The square itself is bustling with cafes, people, artists etc. So many shops around. Just sit here and take it all in.
Awesome place or rather shopping Paradise for people's, full of all brand outlets and departmental store like Macy's, Eatery outlet also Lots to choose from or go to pier 39 from there to relax.

Union Square is the logical “centre” of San Francisco with all the major shops and hotels in or close to it. A couple of coffee shops in the square itself offer a great place to rest weary feet or to wait while wives go shopping!! It is also a great place to people watch although there are high numbers of beggars and vagrants. Transport links are great and the Cable Cars go through the square. There used to be a heart on each corner of the square but there are only 2 left, not sure why!
Show less
yes its most happening place of city. All the major offices and shops are there. Its good to have a walk in the evening. Great view

Union square is right in the middle of SF and has lots of department stores with a Cheesecake factory right on top of one, where from you can have great views over the square.

It seems to attract lots of people sitting or with dogs, homeless and there is lots of activity.

We visited several times: on foot, by car and using the Hop on hop off bus.
Show less
It's a small square, but has a cool vibe day and night. Lots going on in and around the area. Quieter at night!

Union Square is a great spot to relax, people-watch, enjoy whatever activities are being staged or otherwise just doing nothing.

As many times as I have been to Union Square there was something different I found out during this visit? I had my camera and tripod so while my wife was shopping I was simply going to take some pictures. Unfortunately, tripods are a no-no according to venue staff who was patrolling the area making sure people weren't smoking or going through the trash looking for recyclables. He was pleasant but as soon as I set my unit up he came over and said, "sorry to be a pain but to use a tripod you must have a permit!!!" My reaction was WHAT!!!!!!! No worries, I understood he was only doing his job.

Union Square is a must stop as in addition to the plaza there were some interesting stores on the perimeter.

It's a good option to stay in the city that is close to public transport. However unless you are into shopping at high end stores that are likely the same in your own country, go shopping elsewhere. Much more unique stores in the mission district. The square itself doesn't have anything going on and is basically just a concrete slab in the middle of downtown. Skip it unless staying in the area or heading for the train station.

Also it's a pretty gritty area to be honest. So if homeless and cracked out people make you uncomfortable, skip it after dark. We saw a guy overdose on drugs and had to be taken away via ambulance in front of the Westin St Francis (our hotel)at around 6 pm.

This is the main high-end shopping area. This is just like any major city's downtown core.
It's busy, with lots of tourists and just like everywhere in the city, a lot of homeless people milling around.
Union Square itself is great for people watching, there is a café and most hop on/off bus tours start here (in front of Macy's).
You're also a short walk to Chinatown.
Currently there is construction in the area. I believe they are building a subway.

Union Square is a very nice site to explore. I visited Union Square for the atmosphere and the high end shopping. Union Square is most even if you are not spending a lot of money. I recommend visiting this site while in San Francisco.

We had a three night stop over in San Francisco and sat in Union Square people watching on the last day. It's a nice spot sitting in the sun with the cable car on one side and Macy's on the other but we didn't feel safe. There are lots of people begging and if you ignore them they give you a mouthful of bad language. Some people are just simply strange.
We found San Francisco to be a dirty city too. Rubbish is everywhere you look and any available spot has graffiti on it. Shame really as other aspects of San Francisco are really nice.
If you travel here just be on your guard.

I came solely for Apple store visit

I am an Apple fan. I wanted to visit just the Apple store. I did. It's architecturally very neat. You can search for more info on that aspect. There was far too much road work when I visited that really made the whole Union Square less than pleasant.

Great starting point for San Francisco

This square is the center of town. Amidst the shopping stores (a massive Macy's) and the latest award winning designed indoor/outdoor Apple Store is a big plaza where there are bands playing or art exhibits and other activities.

This is also a key stop for all the hop-on hop-off tour busses.

There are the San Francisco hearts painted by famous artist on display at key ends

One can sit at a cafe nearby and watch the crowds go by.

The plaza is rather big and buzzing with activity

Park in the main shopping district
This is the center of the main shopping district in SF. It is a small park and you can sit and watch people. The surrounding buildings and shops form a very nice landscape for photography.

This is an excellent stop whilst in San Fran if you're keen to do some shopping. Don't be expecting discounted prices however as I found the prices to be standard for the mid range brands to the super expensive / high quality labels (Gucci, LV etc)

Macy's is fantastic as it has a his & her building, including 5 levels for men's and I think 7 levels for women's clothing. There's also a Westfield that's close by, and Saks Fifth Avenue as all your uber expensive labels.

See the square and take a selfie!
Our hotel was only a couple of blocks away, so I took the opportunity to walk around and take photos.

What a delight it was to be wandering back to our hotel on,y to come across a swing band in the square, and a who,e bunch of people dancing to the beat. A joy! At other times there were art exhibits. Unfortunately the construction work is an eyesore on one corner but will no doubt lead to something useful. I read that there were a lot of homeless souls here but I saw few, many more in other places. The square itself could use a bit more greenery but on the whole is pleasant.

Fine. A couple of nice cultural aspects for photos. The San Francisco hearts in the square were nice and always interesting with further details. Great people-watching venue with a coffee shop with great coffee. Some market vendors to make things interesting. Worth a visit. Some of the shops are interesting to visit from a visual perspective.

Centrally located, easy access to various means of transport makes getting around SF simple. Lots of places to eat to suit any budget. Highly recommend the area.
This is an interesting area due to the many stores, hotels.... It also is very historical as its name "union Square" implies. Some great photo opportunities here.
Union Square is pretty cool to walk through and sit. Great spot for photos but not much else. There are these giant Hearts that are painted to represent the story of San Fransisco.

Stayed in a hotel just around the corner and had a look round the high end shops. It does not feel safe at all. Many homeless people, most with drug, alcohol or mental health issues. My kids felt very nervous due to all the shouting and swearing. Wouldn't recommend to anyone at all. Even in Macy's there was a homeless man wandering around begging and bothering people. The staff don't seem to bat an eyelid but it can be nerve wracking as a tourist.

The concentration of mentally disturbed people and addicts in the square area is overwhelming. Seeing a homeless man defecating and urinating, half naked, with his pants down yesterday (8/19/17) on a lovely sunny Saturday afternoon (just after the corner of Grant on Post) was pretty much the low point of the day. Union Square itself is a mess, seemingly under endless construction and disarray. Parking in SF is always a challenge, and this time we found the Union Square Garage expensive and hazardous for pedestrians.

Even With Construction - A Nice Square

There is construction at Union Square!

On each visit, the project seems to morph a bit, taking over a different area, or expanding/contracting, like an accordion. On this visit, much of the Southeast corner, was behind barricades.

Still, the Square is a lovely place to be, with two dining venues, and lots of benches.

The plantings were lovely, and probably absorbing the fog, when we walked through.

On this visit, I entered from the Northwest, and spent time in the main plaza, around the central statue, before heading to check out the construction. At that point, due to the elevational difference, I was looking down on the barricades. Work was definitely in progress.

After a stroll, I headed to the Southwest corner, but had to wait for several Hop-On/Hop-Off buses to board. There were a lot of folk heading out for those “tours,” and the sidewalk was congested.

On this visit, there was but one “percussionist,” pounding out a rhythm on various buckets, pots and what-not. Often, there are more, competing in a cacophony of sound. Also, no “protestors” were in evidence.

A nice, short visit, and I only hope that the construction will soon be finished.
Show less
Rode the cable car to Union Square from Fishermans Wharf. Waited in line about an hour for each way.

As a whole I have always liked SFO ... but after this visit someone really needs to get hold of this place... people / homeless hanging around begging ... smoking weed (which I detest) and just generally looking dirty ... Get a Grip SFO

Real crowded square. Can jump on the cable car (long waiting time). But not something really special going on at this square. Also a lot of homeless people on the streets. On some places you smell the pee and it gave us an unsafe feeling with the kids to be here. Relieved we stayed at fishermans wharf and not in a jotel on Union Square.
Show less

If you want shopping you are in the right place. It also seems to be the main hub for transport (tour buses) and places to eat and drink. Clean and very busy. Nice area to sit in the sun and eat outside.

I've been meaning to write this review for sometime now for those visiting SF for the first time. Union Square is one of the shopping districts in the city. It 's full of high end shops and so so restaurants that cater mostly to tourist. For the most part the area is safe and there's lots to see, The downside is the neighborhood is right next to the Tenderloin aka the TL. The TL is full of homeless people and not the safest area in the city. My advice if you're visiting Union Square is DO NOT go pass Taylor Street which is west of Union Square. It's starts to get a little sketch after that. Also do not be afraid to say no to the panhandlers in the area.
Show less
Great shops, Unsafe environment particularly for the solo traveller

The shops in this area are great, a good variety and something for everyone.

Now the reason I give this a poor rating is due to the sheer number of intoxicated homeless people in the area who are constantly hassling or following you around begging. A very sad situation I appreciate, but it does make you feel very uncomfortable and unsafe. One guy was shouting, swearing and hitting things with his fists or a belt. Drug use apparent.

Not a safe area, and I have been to a lot of unsafe places!
Show less
One of my favorite places to sit and people watch

I love grabbing a lunch and then going to sit in union square. It’s a busy place with lots of interesting people to watch. Things going on and shops all around you. A must for a visit to San Francisco.
There open area at the square contained some artwork for sale. Around the square are many stores, restaurants, and a mall. Street performers were playing music and dancing nearby.
all the major and not so major shops are here; many flagship stores and high end department stores are here too. fun shopping experience if you enjoy shopping.

I stayed in a hotel in union square so it was the first place we visited in SF. The area is extremely busy with tour services and promoters everywhere. The square has a high amount of designer shops and I would say it comes across as quite an expensive area with lavish shops and dining areas, which is quite the contrast to the amount of homeless people on the streets.

There are large amounts of homeless in the area which my friends and I originally found quite intimidating and daunting - some homeless would open doors for us without asking and then ask for payment, but did not seem aggravated when we said no. There was one incident at night time in which a man attempted to mug us, but luckily (for us) he walked away to someone else - we hope that person was also ok!

For an area with such expensive shops and rich residents, one would expect less homeless but it's not enough to deter me from visiting or staying in the area again!

Nice urban open space. Flanked by buildings this rectangle is a nice place for a cup of coffee or even just to walk through. Plenty of people milling around. Pretty plants add a touch of green to the space.
A lot of different nationalities in this place, ready to visit San Francisco by bus Also you could go shopping to Macy's and other shops

Our hotel is near here so we thought to have a look around. Macy's takes one side here with shopping all around here as we crossed the square and all around the San Fransico area there seems to be plenty of homeless/ street beggers,
It is the center of San Francisco downtown, with magnificent building around. You may find any top brand commodity here. Sitting on the square to see the pigeon is also enjoyable.

Our Big Bus tour started here. Tony Bennett's self-painted hearts are on display at the four corners of US.

Michael Jackson impersonator danced to a boom box blaring MJ music for tips--fun entertainment. The guy could dance!

This is meeting place and more for outdoor enjoyment:park benches, people watching, etc.
Show less
Nice open space, central location, all the shoping
Central square with all the shopping. Great location with all at walking distance. Best location for hotel and exploration of the city.
4.5 rating to this beautiful full congested center of SF

I believe that, save the chronic panhandling, this is one California's finest and prettiest urban concrete parks. The term park can be innocently misleading. Union Square once a grassy knoll. The photos here on this site will show the transformation that is both liked and hated by locals and tourists alike. Seasonal ice skating and beautiful Christmas tree make this a fun place for kids and adults alike. On sunny days, this is a great place to relax for a tea or coffee during your visit to this city favorite.
Walking about and near this highly congested shopping Mecca is highly recommended, as driving anywhere in the downtown districts of SF is very painful. Congestion, high parking fees and the lack of upgraded infrastructure is why locals only walk in this beautiful and fun neighborhood and historic park area.
Show less
High end shopping district in downtown SF? Yes, please! Even with the current construction, it's a lovely square and area altogether. Go shopping there and don't miss it!
Good central point for hotels and parking.

Vast underground parking is amongst the most secure, and not so expensive, at $36 per 24 hour period, NOT charged for each portion of a calendar day. Lock it and leave it, without questionable parking attendants doing weird things with your car. Some spaces are huge, to prevent door dings. Cable cars, theaters, shopping, and more, are all here, and you can walk for miles from this starting point.
Show less
Square with Free Entertainment and Lots of Shopping

This is really just an open park with a little cafe and entertainment on random days/nights. The shops in the area are a mix of high-end, regular and boutique. Great area to kill time or if you need to get some shopping done. Also, great place to grab non-San Francisco sweatshirts/fleeces when you inevitably arrive in San Francisco expecting California weather and realize you didn't bring enough warm clothing for the 50-70 degree weather.

Note: Macy's Men and Women's stores are two separate shops.

Our hotel was close by so we were in the area a lot. Tour buses leave from this area as well so it can get congested. There were vendors selling art and playing music during the day. At night it gets loud with street performers looking for money. I wouldn't go visit the square itself but there is a lot of good shopping all around it.
Show less
Amazing sales for the 4th July! We got some really good bargains to take back to the UK! Great shopping experience!

This place is center of City. Surrounded by hotels, shop with luxury brand name where you can start visiting city by hop in- hop out bus. For us, this area is less fun than china town, fisherman walf.

High end shops plus a Ross, cool mall, 5 floors, food at the bottom lots of stores, homeless everywhere it is the whole human spectrum from $56 valet parking to mentally ill people living adjacent. Parts smell like pee, the Carl's Jr. had a guard, overall it is enjoyable, eye opening and interesting.

First opened for public in 1850, the square was not very big, only 2.6 acres (1.1 ha) in the heart of SF's downtown surrounded by high-end shopping, hotels, art galleries, theatres, etc.
Got its name as it was used for rallies in support of Union Army during American Civil War. The 30 m tall monument there, erected in 1903 with "victory" statue on top, was to commemorate the triumph of American Navy led by Commodore George Dewey in the Battle of Manila Bay during American - Spanish War.
There were chairs and benches that we could relax on, although, as experienced by some reviewers here, there could be homeless people harassing you which did not happen to us. We came late in the afternoon and not many people were around. From here we had dinner at Cheesecake Factory on Macy's top floor with awesome view of the square and lighted buildings surrounding it.

The High Dollar shopping center of San Francisco, CA.

This place is alive with all sorts of artists, vendors and shopping activities. You need to go here for the scene, history and activities. This is the central location where all activity takes place. Get on a Hop on Hop off bus and tour the city with frequent hop on hop off wherever you want to stop, all for one price. It is well worth it.

The place is the centre point of the city with everything around - shopping place (there is a macy's right in the front of the square), restaurants, all the tours buses have a stop over here. The place has a lot of outdoor cafes and side shops for local stuff. The place gets really crowded which is not a surprise but be a bit cautious of the homeless people sitting on the roadsides although they cause no harm but you never know.. All the business houses are on the same road blocks and the tram runs through as well. A tick-mark on the tour list..
